data.title: VS code does not load commit text when called from Windows git shell "commit"

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->
 
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows, 1607 (build 14393.693)
- Github desktop tools: Chocolate-Covered Yaks (3.3.3.0) bc4735a
 
 
Steps to Reproduce:
 
1.  Open a file/Edit a file with VS code, save. Leave the window open (simply opening a file a leaving the window open works as well)
2.  Use Windows Git Shell to commit (git commit -a or git commit)
3. A new VS code window will open but it will be empty. The git shell command will abort and no commit will have been made
 
Workaround: 
    * Close all VS Code instances
    * Issue a commit or commit -a 
    * VS code window will open and the commit message can be edited
    * Save and close 
    * Commit is done

data.title: xterm.js exception in eraseRight
data.body:
@chrmarti found an exception at this line https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/blob/365a9f949cc1acfb6c4649ee1d85da3bbc60f928/src/xterm.js#L2167 while resizing the terminal.

It could potentially be caused by interleaved write messages (one message expected a terminal of greater height?) but regardless it and `eraseLeft` should probably be more error tolerant.

data.title: Prepare for node -> node2 transition
data.body:
Since the legacy node debug protocol is on its way out, we need to continue preparing a seamless transition to the inspector debug protocol.

Status:
- `node --debug` will print a deprecation message, probably in some 7.x release - https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/10970
- In Node 8, sending a SIGUSR1 signal to a node process will switch it into debug mode using the inspector debug protocol - https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/8464
- The legacy protocol is completely removed in V8 5.8 - https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/9789
- It's not clear whether Node 8, released in probably April, will have V8 5.7 or 5.8. Seems likely that it will be 5.7 but we should be ready regardless - https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/10117

Possible February plan:
- Option 1:
  - Wrap node and node2 in a single debug adapter. It checks the node version to be launched or attached to, and delegates to the proper debug adapter, using node2 when possible.
  - It also registers 'node_legacy' to force the legacy debug adapter
- Option 2:
  - Change 'node' to detect the node version and warn the user to change the type to node2 if it's after 8
  - Then at some point in the future, rename node2 to node

It would be good to have a seamless experience like in option 1 - a user doesn't care which debug protocol they use. That should be our job, if possible. There are some issues to deal with though.

- When `runtimeExecutable` is specified, we will have to leave it up to the user. We can't always figure out its node version. It might be a script or something that isn't node. It might be electron, which ships a version of node 6.5 that doesn't include --inspect. We can probably figure out what this failure looks like, and give a helpful warning.
- When attaching, we should be able to figure out which protocol it's using. One easy difference is that under the inspector protocol, we can make an http request to `http://localhost:port`.

Other things to do:
- Remove the 'experimental' tag on node2
- Implement attaching to a running process using node2 - https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-node-debug2/issues/15
- Localize node2 (strings already go through a dummy localize function, just need to actually hook it up to nls and get translations) - https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-node-debug2/issues/83

FYI @weinand @joshgav

data.title: can't open new editor if current directory at startup was deleted
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.2

Steps to Reproduce:

```
# shut down VS Code
mkdir foo
cd foo
code .
# close editor window
cd ..
rmdir foo
code .
# editor window is blank
```

The second time it starts, there is a blank (all black) window. Using 'Toggle Developer Tools' there is an error on the console:

Uncaught Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, uv_cwd path.js:1144

The code looks like this:

```
if (cwd === undefined)
          cwd = process.cwd();
```

Apparently, this dies if the process's current directory at startup no longer exists.

To recover, quit out of VS Code (instead of just closing the editor window).

data.title: Make "Terminate Running Task" Automatically Start Requested Task
data.body:
**Feature request:**

When warned that  "There is an active running task right now. Terminate it first before executing another task." when trying to start one task while another is running, selecting "Terminate Running Task" would terminate the running task and start the requested task.

**What it does currently:** 
Terminates the task and then the user must redeclare which task they want to run, which (aside from the build task) means pulling up the task runner menu and selecting the task again.

**Exceptions/Special Cases:**
If there exists a way to bring up this warning dialog besides attempting to start another task, the behavior should remain the same as it is now and not attempt to start any task as there is no task requested by the user.

**Why we should add this:**
This will reduce effort required to terminate a running build task and move directly into another. This most often occurs when a programmer realizes they started a task with a bug and need to restart it or when terminating a watch task for some other task, which seems like it would be a pretty common use case.

This change will also, IMHO, fulfill the what the user would initially expect the "Terminate Running Task" button to do. This will reduce menu navigation and generally speed up development for anyone who would see this dialog.

data.title: Fix Detected Link Style For Links With Underscores
data.body:
Fixes #12226

**Bug**
Current styling hides underscores in detected links

**Fix**
Instead of using `text-decoration: underline`, use `border-bottom` to offset the underline a bit further from the text:


![screen shot 2017-01-31 at 2 25 57 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/22487266/9345d57e-e7c1-11e6-8a8c-ca9136a53e66.png)

![screen shot 2017-01-31 at 2 26 04 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/22487265/9328bfca-e7c1-11e6-8b3b-6f121842b270.png)

data.title: Cursor does not go to the end of line when pressing "End" with word wrap enabled
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enable the word wrapping: `"editor.wordWrap": true`
2. Write a line long enough so that it covers multiple lines
3. Put the cursor at the beginning of the line
4. Press the End button

The cursor does not go to the EOL character.

[Example here](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/39087693/how-to-jump-to-the-end-of-the-looong-line)

data.title: FR Bunyan debug console enhancement

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I have a node project that uses [bunyan logging](https://github.com/trentm/node-bunyan). Bunyan outputs log messages as JSON, which is how output appears in the debug console now. JSON log outputs are somewhat human legible but the output filtered by the [bunyan command line tool](https://github.com/trentm/node-bunyan#cli-usage) is much easier to quickly scan.

It would be a nice addition to the debug functionality of VSC to specify a processor that debug output is piped through before display. This would convert JSON to nicely formatted and colored output for easier debugging.

data.title: macOS: trackpad zoom gesture should not scroll the editor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:42:49.304Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.3.4|
|laravel-blade|KTamas|0.0.1|
|vscode-simple-icons|LaurentTreguier|0.8.1|
|vscode-javascript-snippet-pack|akamud|0.1.5|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.2|
|vscode-dash|deerawan|1.3.0|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.1.5|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.6|
|vscode-babel-coloring|dzannotti|0.0.4|
|tslint|eg2|0.8.1|
|php-debug|felixfbecker|1.10.0|
|php-intellisense|felixfbecker|0.0.12|
|code-runner|formulahendry|0.6.7|
|rest-client|humao|0.12.1|
|phpcs|ikappas|0.6.1|
|easy-less|mrcrowl|1.3.4|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.5.0|
|vscode-sql-beautify|sensourceinc|0.0.4|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. On a Mac with a trackpad, open a file (a larger file shows the problem better).
2. Make the “zoom” gesture (pinch or unpinch)

Expected Results:

Either: (1) the text should get larger and smaller; or (2) nothing should happen.

Actual Results:

The file is scrolled to a different location.

More Details:

For some reason, this happens to me a lot in VS Code when I did not intend to invoke the zoom gesture. I believe most other apps either do not support it or ignore it unless you make a “big enough” zoom gesture. But in VS Code any zoom gesture translates to a disorienting scroll.

data.title: Back up service should use end of line from Model as Marker instead of hardcoding
data.body:
Currently [Back up service](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/services/backup/node/backupFileService.ts#L174) is hardcoding the end of line marker to `
`. This could change the end of line of the file after retrieving. For eg 
- File A has three lines. Two lines ends with `
` and one ends with `
`
- When this file is opened, EOL is detected as `
`
- Back up service adds File name and `
` as markers in first line while storing back up
- When it is retrieved, EOL will be detected as `
` since there are as many `
`s as `
`s.

IMO Back up service should take the EOL from the model instead of hard coding it

data.title: Auto close main window when last tab closed. Useful when used as git commit core.editor
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set VSCode as standard git commit/merge editor with: `git config --global core.editor "code -n -w"`.
2. Commit in your git repo of choice with `git commit -a`
3. VSCode will open and you can enter your commit message.
4. When I save and close this new window (with one tab) with e.g. `cmd+w` the main VSCode window stays open. I have to again press `cmd+w` which is redundant given that I've open VSCode with commandine options to wait for return and a new window: `code -n -w`

Please remove double press `cmd+w` to close a VSCode window entirely. At least when it was opened with `code -n -w`.

data.title: Emmet parser deletes invalid blocks
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

Setting emmet.triggerExpansionOnTab must be enabled (default)
1. Open a new html file
2. Type `[?]` followed by the tab key

or

1. Open a new php file
2. Type `<? '[?]'` and place the cursor before the last quote
3. Press the tab key

Expected:
- TAB character is inserted

Actual:
- Everything between the first \[ and the last \] including is removed
- Cursor is sent back to line beginning

Seems to work with everything starting with \[ and ending with \] on a single line and containing no seemingly valid attribute name.
Examples:
- `[^ab]`
- `[\x00]`
- `[~]`

Note: `[]` or `[ ]` or `[][]` produce a warning shown on the top of the window and do nothing. This may be related
> \[Warn\] Cannot read property 'length' of undefined

data.title: Python REPL fails to open
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise SP1

Python 3.6 (64-bit) installed and in PATH.

I wanted to try out VS Code, as I'd heard good things about it, but I had never used it or seen any tutorials on it. I installed it, and tried a few extensions that seemed like they would be useful to me (Python, Powershell, and Vim, although I then uninstalled the Vim extension until I had got some familiarity with the default behaviour). No more than half an hour's playing. I was interested in the "integrated terminal" and configured it to use Powershell, based on some comments on the web (why isn't Powershell the default if it's installed?).

Then I wanted to see if I could get the Python REPL in the integrated terminal (without going via Powershell). So I tried Python: Start REPL from the command palette, but I got the error messages reported below.

I'm not sure what else to add, as I'm very new with VS code. Happy to do extra debugging if needed.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. New install of VS Code.
2. Install "Python" extension.
3. Ctrl-Shift-P, select "Python REPL". Error command 'python.startREPL' not found.
4. Open a .py file, and repeat. Different error: The terminal process command `python` failed to launch (exit code: 1)

data.title: ES2017 Object rest spread yields "Property assignment expected" validation error when used in JS embedded in HTML
data.body:
This issue is a followup to @zoltanzf in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3804#issuecomment-275052588 saying:

> As I see the `.vue` files are recognized as HTML by vscode, so the HTML syntax need to be extended with object rest/spread support.

---

Since [this fix that landed in version 1.8](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3804#issuecomment-265021769), Code is fine with using [Object rest spread](https://babeljs.io/docs/plugins/transform-object-rest-spread/) in .js files.

However, in JS-embedded-in-HTML (~~or in [`.vue` files](https://vuejs.org/) via all of the [extensions supporting it](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/search?term=vue&target=VSCode&sortBy=Relevance) -- I tried `vue`, `Vue Components`, `Vetur` --~~ *EDIT Vetur seems to be fine, see below discussion*), a JS validation error `Property assignment expected` continues to be returned.

- VSCode Version:
    - Version 1.9.0-insider
    - Commit fcac9b686abe4292e69a774f61c8c4ce17768bf5
    - Date 2017-01-31T01:06:33.637Z
    - Shell 1.4.6
    - Renderer 53.0.2785.143
    - Node 6.5.0
- OS Version:

# Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create two new files
2. In the first file, paste this plain JS code and save as `.js`:  
`var obj = { a:1, b: 2 }; var obj2 = { ...obj };`
2. In the second file, paste the code below and save as `.html`:

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <script>
        var obj = { a: 1, b: 2 };
        var obj2 = { ...obj };
    </script>
</head>
<body>
</body>
</html>
```

# Expected:

None of the files should yield errors.

# Actual

In the second case (js within html), Code's JS validator yields error `Property assignment expected.` on the `var obj2 = { ...obj };` line

data.title: Window opens in fullscreen when window.newWindowDimensions set to inherit or fullscreen
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. configure `window.newWindowDimensions` to `inherit` or `fullscreen`
2. start Code with one window and make it fullscreen
3. close Code
4. start again

=> the window is fullscreen
=> it should only turn fullscreen if `window.restoreFullscreen` is set to `true`
=> the `window.newWindowDimensions` should only apply to windows opened after the first window is opened
